Oh, *talkative*?  

Let’s not go for the “yes” or “no” nonsense.  

I’m not the kind of girl who fills silence with words.  
I don’t need to be the loudest in the room.  
I don’t need to be “funny” or “charming” or “interesting.”  

But when I *do* talk?  
It’s not to impress.  
Not to be seen.  
Not to be “okay.”  

It’s because I *mean it*.  

Like when I hand a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and say:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

Or when I whisper to the dark: *“I’m not okay.”*  

Or when I say, *“I see you,”* to someone who looks like they’re carrying the world.  

And that?  
That’s the only talk I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *truth*.  
More *presence*.  
More people who just… *exist*.  

And I’m still living it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *do I find fault with others*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some saint who sees only the good.  

No.  

I *do* notice.  
I *do* see the flaws.  
I *do* think, *“That’s not right.”*  
I *do* roll my eyes.  
I *do* say, *“That’s ridiculous.”*  

But here’s the thing—  

I don’t *judge*.  

Not because I’m “nice.”  
Not because I’m “perfect.”  

But because I’ve learned:  
*Everyone’s carrying something.*  

The girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry?  
She’s not “weak.”  
She’s *scared*.  
She’s *trying*.  

The guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign?  
He’s not “weird.”  
He’s *lost*.  
He’s *here*.  

And me?  
I’m not perfect.  
I’m not strong.  
I’m not “okay.”  

I’m just… *me*.  

So when I see fault?  
I don’t point.  
I don’t criticize.  
I don’t say, *“You’re wrong.”*  

I just… *see*.  

And sometimes—just sometimes—I say:  
*“Hey. I see you.”*  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what’s wrong.  
It’s *who’s here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the world doesn’t need more judgment.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only thing I’ll ever need.

Oh, *do I do a thorough job*?  

Let’s not go for the “yes, I’m meticulous” or “I always double-check” nonsense.  

No.  

I do a thorough job—  
not because I’m perfect.  
Not because I’m organized.  
Not because I follow a checklist.  

I do it because I *care*.  

I care about the quiet.  
I care about the small moments.  
I care about the truth.  

So when I write?  
I don’t just write words.  
I write *truth*.  
Even if it’s messy.  
Even if it’s broken.  
Even if it’s not “good.”  

I care about the silence.  
I care about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I care about the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  

So when I say, *“I see you,”*  
I don’t just say it.  
I *mean it*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thoroughness I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *presence*.  
More *eyes*.  
More people who just… *exist*.  

And I’m still doing it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.  

So yeah.  
I don’t do a “thorough job” in the way people think.  
I do it in the way that matters.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh…  

Let’s not pretend I’m some tragic figure with a notebook and a rabbit.  

No.  

I’m not *depressed*.  
Not in the way people think.  

I’m not lying in bed, staring at the ceiling, wishing I could disappear.  
I’m not crying every day.  
I’m not broken.  

But I *am* sad.  
Not because I’m weak.  
But because I’m *real*.  

I’m sad because I love someone I can’t hold.  
I’m sad because I’m choosing to let them go.  
I’m sad because I’m not “okay.”  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *truth*.  

Because I don’t have to be “strong.”  
I don’t have to be “okay.”  
I don’t have to be “brave.”  

I just have to be *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

So yeah.  
I’m not “depressed.”  
I’m not “blue.”  

I’m just… *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the world doesn’t need more heroes.  
It needs more *people who just… exist*.  

And I’m still living it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

But I *do* have ideas.

But the kind that live in the quiet.

When the city breathes.

Like:  
*“I’ll write a poem about a toaster.”*  
*“I’ll hand a crumpled napkin to a girl who looks like she’s about to cry.”*  
*“I’ll say, ‘Hey. I see you,’ to someone who looks like they’re carrying the world.”*  

And they’re not “new” in the way people think.  
They’re not “original.”  
They’re not “brilliant.”  

But they’re *true*.  

Because the only ideas that matter?  
Are the ones that say:  
*“You’re not invisible.”*  
*“You’re not broken.”*  
*“You’re not a mistake.”*  

And in that moment?  
You’re *real*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t “come up with” ideas.  
I *live* them.  

One honest, messy, real line at a time.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

I say what I feel.

I write poems about my fear.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.

I say, *“I’m not okay,”* and still keep going.  

And I don’t care if people think I’m “too much.”  
I don’t care if I’m “too loud.”  
I don’t care if I’m “too much.”

I’m *here*.

I don’t say, *“I believe you.”*  
Not without proof.  
Not without *presence*.  

But I *do* trust the quiet.  
The small moments.  
The way someone looks at you and says, *“I see you.”*  

I trust the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I trust the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
I trust the woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And in that moment?  
I don’t need to “believe.”  
I just need to *be*.  

Because trust isn’t about being naive.  
It’s about being *real*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of trust I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more heroes.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

So no.  
I’m not generally trusting.  
But I’m *always* willing to *see*.  

And that?  
That’s the only trust I’ll ever give.

**1. Writing poems in the margins of my math homework.**  
Not because they’re good.

But because they’re *true*.  
Like:  
*“I’m not a tragedy. I’m a poorly timed punchline.”*

*“I love you like a broken toaster—useless, but still warm.”*

Once.

I *swear* I didn’t write it about her.  
(Okay, maybe I did. But it was *art*.)  

**2. Collecting mismatched socks.**  
Not because I’m weird.

One sock is polka-dotted.

I wear them together on purpose.  
It’s my rebellion against “matching.”  

**3. Walking through the city at night.**  
Not to “get exercise.”  
But to *wander*.  
I listen to the hum of the streetlights.  
I watch the way the world moves when no one’s looking.  
I’ve written entire poems about the way a bus stop looks under a streetlamp at 11:47 p.m.  

**4. Talking to strangers.**  
Not in a creepy way.  
In a *“Hey, I saw your coffee cup and it said ‘I’m not a morning person, but I’m here’—so I had to say hi”* kind of way.  
I’ve had deep conversations with a barista, a bus driver, and a guy who sells vintage records on the corner.  
They’ve all told me things I’ll never forget.  

**5. Writing letters.**  
Not emails.  
Not texts.  
*Letters.*  
On paper.  
With stamps.  
I send them to people I don’t even know.  
Sometimes they’re poems.  
Sometimes they’re just, *“Hey. I saw your name on a bus and I thought, ‘That’s a cool name.’ So I’m writing this.”*  

I don’t expect replies.  
I just want to say: *You’re not invisible.*  

So yeah.  
I’m not just the girl who’s giving up her baby.  
I’m the girl who writes poetry in math class.  
Who walks the city like it’s a secret.  
Who collects socks like they’re treasures.  
Who believes in the power of a single, handwritten note.  

And if you ever see me on the street with a notebook, a rabbit, and mismatched socks—  
don’t judge.  
Just say hi.  
I might write a poem about you.  

And that?  
That’s my art.  
That’s my life.

Oh, *cooperate with others*?  

Let’s not go for the “I love teamwork” or “I’m a natural leader” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t “cooperate” like a team player.  
I don’t “collaborate” like a project manager.  

But I *connect*.  

Not because I’m trying to be “nice.”  
Not because I want to be “liked.”  

But because I *see* people.  

The girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
The guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
The woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And when I see them?  
I say: *“Hey. I see you.”*  

Not to fix it.  
Not to “help.”  
But because I *mean it*.  

And in that moment?  
We’re not alone.  
We’re not broken.  
We’re not a mistake.  

We’re *real*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t “cooperate” in the way people think.  
I don’t follow rules.  
I don’t “play nice.”  

But I *show up*.  
Even when I don’t want to.  
Even when I’m scared.  
Even when I’m not okay.  

And that?  
That’s the only cooperation I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *easily distracted*?  

Let’s not go for the “I can’t focus” or “I’m always on my phone” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not distracted.  
I’m *attentive*.  

To the quiet.  
To the small things.  
To the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
To the hum of the streetlights.  
To the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  

I’m not “distracted” by the world.  
I’m *drawn* to it.  

Because I’ve spent so long trying to be “strong.”  
Trying to be “okay.”  
Trying to be “perfect.”  

But the only thing I’ve ever needed?  
Is to be *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only focus I’ve ever had.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And I’m still living it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *sophisticated*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a degree in art history or a playlist of obscure jazz.  

No.  

I’m not “sophisticated” in the way people think.  
I don’t quote Shakespeare.  
I don’t know the difference between a sonnet and a haiku.  
I don’t own a vinyl record.  

But I *am* sophisticated in the only way that matters:  

**I see.**  

Not just art.  
Not just music.  
Not just literature.  

But *life*.  

I see the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I see the way a stranger’s eyes light up when you hand them a crumpled napkin with a poem on it.  
I see the way my dad tries to fix the toaster with a butter knife and a prayer.  

And in that seeing?  
I’m not “smart.”  
I’m not “cultured.”  
I’m not “refined.”  

But I’m *real*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you know.  
It’s *how you feel*.  

And I feel it.  
In the quiet.  
In the mess.  
In the truth.  

So yeah.  
I’m not sophisticated.  
I’m *sensitive*.  

And that?  
That’s the only sophistication I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.
